title: ‘Poets are the tramps of literature’ (2012-06-16)
Excerpt: The piece explores the role of poets in the literary world, portraying them as outsiders or "tramps" who often operate on the margins of mainstream literary culture. Armitage discusses the creative and social aspects of poetry, reflecting on the perception of poets as independent figures who resist conventional literary norms. The piece examines the challenges poets face, particularly the lack of financial stability, yet highlights the enduring value and significance of poetry as an art form.

title: A delicate lack of rant (1973-03-29)
Excerpt: This is a very important book. It contains 584 poems by poets from Wilfrid Scanwen Blunt to  Brien Patten, and it has no precedent in range or scale. The reviewer discusses the balance and restraint found in artistic and literary expressions of the book, where the absence of excessive emotional outbursts or aggressive tones ("ranting") enhances the effectiveness of the work. By focusing on measured, thoughtful, and understated presentations, the piece reflects on how moderation in tone can often produce a more profound impact on audiences compared to overly dramatic or forceful styles.
works: "[The Oxford Book of Twentieth Century English Verse (1973)](apdp.work.000105)"

title: A Minority Art (1959-06-18)
Excerpt: This is a poetry anthology by 39 South African writers, including those who were not born in the country but contributed to its European affairs, creative and social development. In its introduction by Guy Butler, he said: it is a minority art, divorced from the Afrikaans, the African, Coloured and the Asiatic majority.  It discusses the status of poetry as a niche art form, often appreciated by a select audience rather than the mainstream. It addresses how poetry, despite being a powerful form of artistic expression, struggles to gain widespread popularity compared to other forms of literature. The piece also reflects on the role of poets in society and the challenges they face in a world that may not fully recognize the value of their contributions. Poetry is presented as a minority pursuit, cherished by few but deeply impactful.

title: A torch kept burning (1994-08-08)
Excerpt: The article "A Torch Kept Burning" reflects on the legacy and continued influence of Alan Paton, exploring how their ideas or ideals have been preserved and passed down through time. The piece discusses the ways in which this "torch" of his influence has remained relevant and impactful, likely through cultural, historical, or political lenses. It examines both the historical context and the ongoing significance of this legacy.
contributor.name: ["Paton, Alan"]

title: African literature's hero honoured (2007-06-13)
Excerpt: The article celebrates the recognition of a prominent figure, Chinua Achebe, in African literature for their significant contributions to the literary landscape. The piece highlights the author's impact on storytelling, culture, and identity, emphasizing how their work has inspired generations of writers and readers. It discusses various accolades received by the author, reflecting a growing appreciation for African literature in the global context. The article also addresses the broader themes present in the author’s works, including the struggle for freedom, cultural heritage, and the complexities of modern African life. This acknowledgment not only honors the individual’s achievements but also elevates the importance of African narratives in the literary canon.
contributor.name: ["Achebe, Chinua 'Albert Chinualumogu'"]

title: Afrikaner writers' war on the censor (1975-07-16)
Article title: Afrikaner writers' war on the censor
Excerpt: The article discusses the growing resistance among Afrikaner writers against censorship imposed by the apartheid regime in South Africa. It highlights the efforts of authors to assert their freedom of expression and challenge the restrictions placed on their literary works. The article emphasizes the significance of literature as a tool for social commentary and political resistance, showcasing how writers use their craft to confront oppressive systems and advocate for change. Interviews and examples of notable authors are included, revealing their commitment to authenticity and the importance of voice in the face of censorship. And underscores the broader implications of these struggles for artistic freedom and the role of literature in shaping societal discourse during a tumultuous period in South African history.
contributor.name: ["Breytenbach, Breyten"]

title: An author m search of humility (1991-10-25)
Article title: An author m search of humility
Excerpt: The article looks into the personal and professional journey of an acclaimed author and poet, Ben Okri, who grapples with the concept of humility in the literary world. It explores the tension between an author's success and the desire for authenticity, highlighting how public recognition can create a disconnect from one's true self and values. Through interviews and reflections, the article illustrates the author's quest to remain grounded amidst fame and critical acclaim. It examines the impact of literary expectations on creativity and self-perception, revealing the struggles of maintaining integrity in a competitive environment. Also, the piece tells of the importance of humility as a guiding principle for writers, suggesting that genuine connection to one's work and audience is essential for lasting impact.
contributor.name: ["Okri, Ben"]

title: An ex-convict runs out of convictions (1993-12-09)
Article title: An ex-convict runs out of convictions
Excerpt: The article explores the life of a former convict, Breyten Breytenbach, who struggles to reintegrate into society after serving time. It delves into the challenges he faces as he attempts to rebuild his life, grappling with the stigma of his past and the complexities of navigating a world that often views ex-convicts with suspicion. Through personal anecdotes and reflections, the article highlights the emotional and psychological toll of incarceration, as well as the societal barriers that hinder successful rehabilitation. The narrative also touches on themes of redemption, personal responsibility, and the search for a new identity. It emphasizes the importance of compassion and understanding in helping former inmates find their footing and contribute positively to society.
contributor.name: ["Breytenbach, Breyten"]

title: Ancient And Modern In English Verse (1956-07-19)
Article title: Ancient And Modern In English Verse
Excerpt: The article examines the interplay between traditional themes and contemporary expressions in English poetry. It reflects on how modern poets draw inspiration from ancient texts and styles, creating a dialogue between past and present. The piece discusses various poets and their works, highlighting the ways in which they incorporate classical motifs, forms, and techniques while addressing contemporary issues and experiences. The article emphasizes the richness of this fusion, showcasing how modern English verse can both honor and reinvent ancient traditions. It underscores the ongoing relevance of historical influences in shaping the voices of today's poets and celebrates the dynamic evolution of English literature. The discussion also points to the importance of this literary heritage in understanding the broader cultural and artistic movements within the English-speaking world
contributor.name: ["Campbell, Roy", "Plomer, William"]

Excerpt: This announcement says of the establishment of a prestigious literary award aimed at recognizing outstanding contributions to English literature. The prize, valued at £1,000, is intended to encourage writers across various genres, highlighting the importance of literary excellence in the post-war era. It outlines the criteria for eligibility and the selection process, emphasizing the award's commitment to celebrating both established and emerging voices. It also discusses the potential impact of the prize on the literary community, fostering innovation and creativity among authors. The announcement signals a growing recognition of the significance of literature in society and the need to support writers in their artistic endeavors. The prize aims to inspire new works and elevate the profile of literature in public consciousness.

Article title: Anthology of poets gathers, we know it; to commend inverse many readings diverse
Excerpt: The article highlights a newly released anthology, Poetry Panassus, that celebrates a wide range of poetic voices and styles. It explores the anthology's mission to showcase diverse perspectives and themes within contemporary poetry, emphasizing the importance of varied readings in enriching the literary landscape. The piece reviews several contributors, noting how their works reflect different cultural backgrounds and experiences, thus creating a vibrant tapestry of modern poetry. The article also discusses the anthology's structure and the selection process, underscoring the editorial team's commitment to inclusivity and representation. By bringing together these varied voices, the anthology aims to foster a greater appreciation for poetry's transformative power and its ability to connect readers across different contexts and backgrounds.

title: Antonio Jacinto (1991-07-05)
Excerpt: The article focuses on the life and work of the prominent Angolan poet and writer Antonio Jacinto. It highlights Jacinto's significant contributions to literature and his role in the cultural and political landscape of Angola, particularly during its struggle for independence. The article discusses his poetry, characterized by themes of nationalism, identity, and social justice, reflecting the experiences of his people. It also notes Jacinto's involvement in the anti-colonial movement and how his literary work served as both a form of resistance and a means of promoting cultural pride. The piece emphasizes the importance of Jacinto's legacy in contemporary African literature and the continued relevance of his messages in today's sociopolitical context.

Article title: BBC awards snub the champions of popular jazz

title: Between France And Africa (1959-08-13)
Excerpt: The article explores the complex cultural and political relationships between France and various African nations during a time of significant change with interest on Senghor, Léopold Sédar. The piece examines the impact of colonialism and the evolving identity of African countries as they navigate their independence movements. The correspondent highlights the cultural exchanges that have emerged from this relationship, particularly in the realms of art, literature, and music. The article also discusses the tensions that exist as African nations seek to assert their independence while maintaining ties to France. By providing insights into the perspectives of both French and African voices, the article sheds light on the intricate dynamics at play and the potential for future collaboration.
contributor.name: ["Senghor, Léopold Sédar"]

title: Between the covers of the Booker Prize (1992-10-13)
Article title: Between the covers of the Booker Prize
Excerpt: The article delves into the significance of the Booker Prize in the literary world and its impact on authors and their works. It examines the history of the award, its selection process, and the notable novels that have received recognition. The piece highlights the prize's role in promoting literary excellence and bringing attention to both established and emerging writers. Additionally, it discusses the diverse themes and styles represented in the shortlisted books, showcasing how the award reflects contemporary societal issues and the evolving landscape of literature. The article also touches on the influence of the Booker Prize on publishing trends and reader preferences, illustrating its lasting legacy in the promotion of quality fiction.

title: Birago Diop (1989-11-27)
Excerpt: The article pays tribute to the renowned Senegalese poet and storyteller, Birago Diop. It explores Diop's significant contributions to African literature, particularly his role in revitalizing traditional oral storytelling through his poetry. The piece highlights his themes of cultural heritage, identity, and the interconnectedness of life and death, reflecting the rich spiritual and cultural tapestry of African society. Diop's work is characterized by its lyrical quality and deep resonance with African folklore, making him a prominent figure in the literary world. The article also discusses Diop's influence on contemporary African writers and his commitment to promoting the African voice in literature. Through his innovative blending of oral tradition with written form, Diop's legacy continues to inspire generations of poets and storytellers, solidifying his place in the pantheon of African literary greats.
contributor.name: ["Diop, Birago"]

title: Booker author says dome must connect 'all our faiths' (1998-01-07)
Article title: Booker author says dome must connect 'all our faiths'
Excerpt: The article discusses remarks made by a Booker Prize-winning author, Ben Okri, regarding the importance of interfaith dialogue and understanding. The author emphasizes that the newly proposed dome, intended to be a space for unity, should serve as a symbol of connection among various religious communities. He does this by writing a poem "Ode to Dome" published by Times. The piece highlights the need for increased cooperation and mutual respect among different faiths, particularly in the context of a rapidly changing global landscape. By advocating for a shared understanding of spirituality and humanity, the author believes in the potential of literature and art to bridge divides and foster dialogue. The article also reflects on how narratives can play a crucial role in addressing contemporary societal challenges, encouraging readers to reflect on their beliefs and the connections that bind us all.
contributor.name: ["Okri, Ben"]

title: Books Of The Week. (1892-01-14)
Excerpt: The article discusses various literary and cultural developments of the time, reflecting on the emerging trends in literature and the arts. It examines the impact of notable writers and their contributions to contemporary thought, showcasing a mix of poetry, prose, and criticism. The piece highlights the evolving landscape of literary genres and the increasing importance of cultural critique in shaping public discourse. It also features insights into upcoming literary events and publications, emphasizing the role of the press in promoting literary voices. The article serves as a snapshot of the vibrant literary scene of the late 19th century, capturing the spirit of innovation and the search for new forms of expression that characterized this dynamic period in history.

title: Brazilian Lesson in Race Assimilation (1966-02-07)
Excerpt: The article explores Brazil's unique approach to racial assimilation, particularly how it contrasts with the racial tensions in other parts of the world, such as the United States during the civil rights era. The piece examines Brazil’s multi-ethnic society, highlighting the historical factors that have contributed to its more fluid racial dynamics, including colonization, African slavery, and indigenous integration. While acknowledging the existence of racial inequalities, the article presents Brazil as a model where inter-racial mixing has led to greater social cohesion compared to other nations with more rigid racial divisions. It also discusses how Brazilian society’s approach to race could offer lessons to other countries grappling with racial integration and equality. The article positions Brazil as a complex but hopeful example of how race and identity can be navigated in diverse societies.
contributor.name: ["Senghor, Léopold Sédar"]

title: Building a sense of unity (1990-07-23)
Excerpt: The article discusses efforts to foster unity in diverse and multicultural societies. It emphasizes the importance of shared values, cooperation, and communication in overcoming divisions related to race, ethnicity, and social class. The piece explores various strategies employed by institutions, governments, and communities to promote inclusiveness, addressing issues such as prejudice and inequality. The article also highlights the role of education and the arts in creating spaces for dialogue and mutual understanding. Through cultural exchange programs, dance (like Odia Ofeimum's poems worked into staged by dancers), literary initiatives, and social reforms, the article underscores the need to strengthen social cohesion by recognizing commonalities rather than differences, thus building a more harmonious and integrated society. It advocates for a collective approach to addressing systemic challenges in order to promote a more unified and peaceful environment.
contributor.name: ["Ofeimun, Odia"]

title: Byron the rover comes to rest at the abbey (1969-05-09)
Article title: Byron the rover comes to rest at the abbey
Excerpt: The article reflects on the literary and historical significance of the poet Lord Byron. It focuses on the poet’s legacy and his final resting place in Westminster Abbey, highlighting how Byron, once seen as a controversial and rebellious figure, had come to be honored alongside Britain's greatest literary figures. The article traces Byron’s tumultuous life, his travels, and his rebellious nature, which made him both celebrated and vilified during his time. The piece tells of the importance of his works and contributions to English literature, noting how time has softened the public’s perception of Byron, allowing his literary genius to shine through and gain recognition in one of England's most revered cultural institutions.
contributor.name: ["Plomer, William"]

Excerpt: The letters discuss the contenders for the role of Poet Laureate in Britain following the death of Cecil Day-Lewis. They explore the significance of the position, which has historically been seen as both an honor and a burden, requiring the appointed poet to create verse for national occasions. They list possible successors, including notable poets and writers, while examining the challenges and expectations that come with the role. They highlight the tension between artistic freedom and the demands of public service, noting how the role has evolved over time.

title: Capturing the heartbeat of humanity (2002-12-07)
Excerpt: The article reflects on the power of literature and the arts in conveying universal human experiences. It explores how various authors and poets tap into emotions such as love, loss, joy, and sorrow, creating works that resonate across cultures and time periods. The piece emphasizes the role of literature in capturing the essence of the human condition, addressing themes of survival, resilience, and shared humanity. By focusing on diverse writers and their creative processes, the article illustrates how storytelling, whether through prose or poetry, bridges the gap between individuals and communities, allowing readers to connect with stories from different walks of life. It also touches on the role of the written word in fostering empathy, understanding, and social cohesion in a rapidly changing world.

title: Commonwealth verse: in the thick of a war of images (1972-04-13)
Article title: Commonwealth verse: in the thick of a war of images
Excerpt: The Times article discusses the role of Commonwealth poets in reflecting and shaping public perception during times of conflict. It emphasizes how poetry from Commonwealth countries grapples with the realities of war, colonialism, and independence struggles, using imagery and symbolic language to challenge imperial narratives. The piece highlights how poets engage with political and social issues, transforming personal and collective experiences of trauma into powerful artistic expressions. By focusing on the poets' ability to distill complex emotions into concise verse, the article shows the potency of poetry as a tool for resistance and self-expression in postcolonial societies. It explores how Commonwealth poets balance the tension between local traditions and global influences, using their works to build new cultural identities.
contributor.name: ["Wright, David", "Plomer, William", "Campbell, Roy"]

title: Compensations in culture (1968-10-09)
Excerpt: The article explores how the arts and culture can offer solace during turbulent times. The piece argues that while material or political losses may create feelings of despair, cultural engagement provides a form of compensation, helping people cope with uncertainty and change. It highlights how literature, theater, music, and visual arts become more significant during moments of crisis, offering emotional and intellectual refuge. The article discusses how different cultural works can inspire reflection, broaden understanding, and provide comfort by addressing universal human concerns. It tells of the belief that culture is not just a luxury but a necessary part of the human experience, fostering resilience and continuity despite the pressures of political and social upheaval.

title: Couple went shopping for baby clothes and died in last embrace (2013-09-24)
Article title: Couple went shopping for baby clothes and died in last embrace
Excerpt: The Times article recounts a tragic and heart-wrenching story of a young couple who were caught in a deadly terrorist attack at the Westgate shopping mall in Nairobi, Kenya. The couple, who were expecting their first child, were found dead in each other's arms after the horrific siege. The article provides details of the terror attack, the human stories of victims, and the ongoing search and rescue efforts at the mall. It also reflects on the broader context of the attack, discussing the actions of the militants and the responses of the Kenyan authorities and international community. It also mentions deaths of prominent people and poets from Africa.

title: Craig Brown (1991-10-24)

It includes the characteristic blend of criticism and lighthearted insights into both contemporary and historical events like the Booker prize, bringing attention to cultural figures and phenomena. title: Critics' Choice: Literature (1990-05-24)

The piece offers insights into the contemporary literary scene, highlighting various authors, books, and emerging trends in literature. It reflects the critical reception of both established and new voices in the literary world. It also serves as a guide for readers interested in exploring a variety of genres, offering recommendations that span multiple literary forms. This is part of a broader cultural conversation about literature's role in society and the critical standards applied to it.

title: Cuckolded by a woman! (1982-03-13)
Excerpt: The article addresses themes of infidelity and relationships, exploring the dynamics between genders in the context of romantic entanglements. It offers a critical lens on the societal implications of being cuckolded, reflecting on cultural attitudes toward love, betrayal, and gender roles. The piece also delves into the emotional impact of such experiences, questioning traditional narratives around fidelity and the expectations placed on individuals within relationships. This article contributes to broader discussions surrounding marriage, love, and the complexities of human interactions, inviting readers to consider the multifaceted nature of personal relationships and the social constructs that shape them.

title: DarK-horse choices hint at new Booker controversy (1992-09-10)

It highlights how these "dark horse" candidates may disrupt traditional expectations and challenge the mainstream literary establishment. The piece examines the implications of such choices for the literary community and the reception of the award itself, suggesting that including unconventional authors could lead to debates about quality and merit in literature. Furthermore, the article raises questions about the role of the Booker Prize in promoting diverse voices and innovative storytelling, positioning the award as a crucial player in the ongoing conversation about literary recognition and the evolving landscape of contemporary literature.
contributor.name: ["Hope, Christopher"]

It reflects on how poets contribute to cultural and intellectual life, emphasizing the timelessness of poetry despite shifts in public interest. The piece shows the poetry's power to evoke emotions, foster critical thinking, and shape societal values, calling attention to poets' lasting influence on readers and the broader literary community.

title: Exploding like poets (1994-02-07)
Excerpt: In "Exploding like poets," published in The Times on 7 February 1994, Stephen Spender reflects on the dynamic and often volatile nature of poetry and poets. Spender discusses how poets, driven by intense emotions and a need for expression, can create works that feel like powerful bursts of creativity. He explores the psychological and emotional forces behind poetry, focusing on how poets navigate personal and societal challenges through their art. The article touches on themes of inspiration, the role of poets in society, and the tension between personal turmoil and the act of creation.

title: Extract (2007-08-25)

Ahmad questions identity, belonging, and the complexity of multicultural experiences, with particular attention to how these themes are portrayed in poetry and literature. The text might explore the tensions between tradition and modernity, and the ways in which individuals navigate these forces in a globalized world.
contributor.name: ["Saro-Wiwa, Ken"]

title: F. T. Prince (2003-08-08)
Excerpt: The article reflects on the life and work of poet F. T. Prince, offering an overview of his literary contributions. Known for his elegant and thoughtful poetry, Prince’s works often delve into philosophical reflections and human experiences, marked by a careful attention to language and form. The piece discusses his impact on British poetry and his influence on subsequent generations of poets. Prince's career spans several decades, and his poetry, often introspective and formal, examines themes such as war, history, and identity.
contributor.name: ["Prince, Frank Templeton 'F. T.'"]

title: Fame and fortune? (1993-09-21)
Excerpt: In the article "Fame and fortune?" published in The Times on September 21, 1993, Craig Brown explores the complex relationship between celebrity culture and the literary world. Brown examines how fame can influence a writer's career, often overshadowing their artistic integrity and the quality of their work. The piece looks into the allure of celebrity, discussing how it can be both a boon and a burden for authors. The article lfeatures examples of renowned writers like Ben Okri whose fame has affected their reception, as well as commentary on the changing dynamics of literary success in the contemporary landscape.
contributor.name: ["Okri, Ben"]

title: Fifty Years Of Poetry (1953-09-16)
Excerpt: The article "Fifty Years Of Poetry," published in The Times on September 16, 1953, reflects on the evolution of poetry over the past five decades, highlighting key movements, influential poets, and significant changes in style and themes. The piece traces the transition from traditional forms to modernist experimentation, noting how societal changes influenced poetic expression. It discusses notable poets who shaped the literary landscape, their contributions to the craft, and how the poetic voice has adapted to reflect contemporary issues.
contributor.name: ["Wright, David"]

title: Happy Easter (1960-04-14)
Excerpt: The article "Happy Easter" by George Cloyne, published on 14 April 1960 in The Times, reflects on Easter celebrations, focusing on themes of renewal, joy, and the cultural significance of the holiday. Cloyne discusses how various communities and poets mark the occasion and the deeper meaning of Easter beyond the festivities. He mentions that during the festive period, William Plomer was preparing a new edition of Kilvert's Diaries.

title: Has the Muse lost her touch (1986-05-06)
Article title: Has the Muse lost her touch
Excerpt: In "Has the Muse Lost Her Touch", published in The Times on May 6, 1986, Robert Nye explores whether modern poets still retain the traditional inspiration of the "Muse," a classical source of artistic creativity. Nye reflects on the current state of poetry, questioning whether contemporary works live up to the power, depth, and mystery traditionally associated with the Muse. He critiques the commercialization of art, expressing concern over whether poets have lost a sense of timelessness and connection to mythic or spiritual sources of inspiration.
contributor.name: ["Wright, David"]

title: Hearing with the inner ear (1992-06-06)
Excerpt: The article delves into how individuals can tap into deeper levels of perception, especially in the context of artistic and creative expression by citing David Wright. It explores how musicians, writers, and poets utilize this form of intuitive "listening" to enhance their work, making them more attuned to subtleties in sound, meaning, and emotional depth that transcend surface-level hearing. This article also features David Wright's poem "An appearance of success".
contributor.name: ["Wright, David"]

title: History and Poetry of the Scottish Border.* (1878-04-29)
Article title: History and Poetry of the Scottish Border.*
Excerpt: The article discusses the rich historical and poetic traditions of the Scottish Border region, reflecting on the deep connection between its turbulent past and the literary expressions that arose from it. The piece shows the significant events and figures from the region's history, as well as the poetry that captures its spirit and legacy, emphasizing how the area’s tumultuous history has influenced its cultural and poetic identity.
contributor.name: ["Hamilton, William Robert 'W. R.'"]

title: History lesson wears a smile (1992-02-15)

Housman and Oscar Wilde. These manuscripts and letters reveal personal insights and lesser-known aspects of their lives and work, sparking interest from collectors and scholars alike.

title: Illegal poetry (2005-11-15)
Excerpt: The article "Illegal poetry" published in The Times on November 15, 2005, discusses how poetry and literature have often been used as forms of protest in regions where free speech is suppressed. The piece highlights how writers in oppressive regimes continue to challenge authority by disseminating their work covertly, defying censorship laws. It explores the risks poets face, including imprisonment, and celebrates their resilience in keeping the spirit of resistance alive through words.

title: Imagination knows no frontiers (1993-03-31)
Excerpt: The article celebrates the power of the human imagination to transcend boundaries, whether cultural, national, or political. It highlights how creativity and artistic expression can bring diverse people together, allowing them to share common experiences, dreams, and ideas across borders. And emphasizes the universal nature of art, literature, and storytelling as mediums that bridge divides and foster understanding among different societies.

title: In the rotten heart of Africa (1997-05-31)
Article title: In the rotten heart of Africa
Excerpt: Sam Kiley's article, "In the rotten heart of Africa" (The Times, 31 May 1997), offers a grim exploration of the ongoing civil unrest and the brutal consequences of failed governance in the Democratic Republic of Congo (formerly Zaire). Kiley highlights the pervasive corruption, violence, and suffering endured by civilians, emphasizing the lack of international attention and humanitarian aid. The piece paints a harrowing portrait of the country's descent into chaos under the dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko and the impacts on the region's political stability.
contributor.name: ["Lumumba, Patrice Hemery"]

She co-founded the Marvell Press with her husband George Hartley, becoming pivotal in publishing The Less Deceived by Philip Larkin in 1955. Her contributions shaped Larkin's literary career and left an enduring mark on British poetry. The article highlights her efforts in advancing poetry and building relationships with notable poets of her time.

His writings often reflected themes of exile, cultural identity, and the African experience, resonating deeply with readers worldwide.

title: The editor lied (1991-01-18)
Excerpt: John Haynes writes about the process through which African poems were selected for publication in The Heinemann Book of African Poetry in English. In a piece he entitled "The Editor Lied" referring to the criteria adopted by Adewale Maja-Pearce, the editor who selected the poems that appeared in the book, Haynes expressed doubt about the true nature of excellence as the criteria for the selection. The piece was published in The Times Literary Supplement of Friday, Januray18, 1991. He argued that the criteria was anything but excellent to have excluded poets such as Okot p'Bitek and Mazisi Kuneni while giving ample space to a relatively new poet like Frank Chipasula, who he described as "relative novice".

title: The Word in four ear, London (1998-12-09)
Article title: The Word in four ear, London
Excerpt: The Times article reviews a London-based event, The World London Festival of Literature, centered around the interplay of spoken word and sound. The article explores how this multi-sensory performance incorporates elements of literature, storytelling, and auditory experiences. It highlights the creative fusion between words and music, focusing on how these elements come together to evoke emotional responses from the audience.

Article title: The writers in the vanguard of an African revolution

The article highlights how these authors are pushing boundaries by addressing themes such as postcolonialism, identity, and societal transformation, marking a significant cultural shift in Africa’s literary history.

title: Thirties talent unripe (1989-03-09)
Excerpt: Peter Ackroyd critiques the work of younger authors, William Plomer, Roy Campbell and others, who, though promising, have yet to fully mature as writers. Ackroyd evaluates the potential and limitations of these authors, highlighting how many are still refining their craft. The review focuses on the themes of ambition and creative struggle during the formative years of literary careers, with an emphasis on how time is needed to reach full creative potential.
contributor.name: ["Plomer, William", "Campbell, Roy"]

title: Too clever by half (1993-10-20)
Excerpt: Lynne Truss offers a witty critique of the literary pretensions often displayed by certain writers. She explores the tension between cleverness and clarity in writing, suggesting that an overemphasis on stylistic flair can detract from the overall message and accessibility of a piece. Truss argues for a more straightforward approach, emphasizing that good writing should prioritize communication over showiness.

Minshull discusses how this shift is driven by the desire to connect more deeply with audiences and the increasing emphasis on the performative aspects of literature.

title: William Plomer: Classical Anger At Race Prejdice (1973-09-28)
Article title: William Plomer: Classical Anger At Race Prejdice
Excerpt: The article  examines the works and legacy of poet William Plomer, particularly focusing on his responses to racial prejudice. The piece describes Plomer's classical influences and his ability to weave personal and societal themes into his poetry, and reflects on how his experiences, both as a South African and a writer, shaped his understanding of race relations and informed his literary output. The article argues that Plomer's work remains relevant in contemporary discussions about race,
contributor.name: ["Plomer, William"]

title: Wole Soyinka (2009-05-30)
Excerpt: The article provides an insightful overview of the life and work of Nigerian playwright and poet Wole Soyinka, the first African laureate to win the Nobel Prize in Literature. The piece explores Soyinka's significant contributions to literature and political activism, highlighting his fearless critiques of authoritarianism and his commitment to justice. It discusses Soyinka's use of language and theatricality, emphasizing how his experiences of exile and imprisonment have shaped his narratives and poetic expressions.

title: In their own words (1989-08-22)
Excerpt: This report was written by Tony Patrick in The Times edition of Tuesday, August 22, 1989 with the title "In their own words". It was about a series of readings at the South Bank Center in London entitled "Putting the L in Word". It featured eight Commonwealth writers from some Caribbean countries, Australia and Africa. Writers who participated were Lorna Goodison, Olive Senior, Ama Ata Aidoo, Gabriel Okara, Antigone Kefala, Fay Zwicky, Archie Weller, and Derek Walcott. The program, according to Patrick intended to explore the different ways these writers had developed in the postcolonial world, building on their absorption of English, American, European and other influences but finding their own voices and becoming increasingly popular in their own country.
Notes: Excerpt from duplicate entry: The article presents series of literary events that will hold like the South Bank Center event. It goes on to announce The Voice Box event and the winner of the Commonwealth prize and other events.

title: The Times Diary (1975-06-17)
Excerpt: In The Times Diary section of The Times published on Tuesday, June 17, 1975, under the authorship of PHS (as abbreviated), this entery was made of the event that mentioned an African poet, Atukwei Okai of Ghana. Okai's name appeared under the title "Missing Poets" which had captured the idea of poets who did not attend the 1975 Poetry International, a readings event presented by the Poetry Book Society. Of all the international participants scheduled to attend, PHS reported that Okai was the only one who had made the "international" idea of the event real with his participation. It was an article of few lines length.
contributor.name: ["Okai, Atukwei 'John'", "Okai, Atukwei 'John'"]

title: Between the Acts (1987-08-21)
Excerpt: Sympathetic commentators sometimes claim that the Afrikaner people of South Africa are motivated not by race but by culture. The Afrikaners' first concern, so the argument goes, is not to favour whites by oppressing blacks, but to preserve the Afrikaner language, religion, and fragile cultural identity in the face of both extreme hostility within and without South Africa.

title: Pariah's path (2009-08-07)
Excerpt: A Young Andre Brink once drove "an iron stake" through the "painted throat" of a sister's favourite doll before burying it in a shallow grave. Remorse over the act drove him further into the arms of the Dutch Reformed Church, whose strict Calvinism bolstered Afrikaner's sense of election and isolation on the southern tip of Africa.

title: Multiracial pens (1983-09-16)
Excerpt: South African reflects the turbulence and confusion of a country where everything is being questioned as never before. Roy Campbell once said in a broad cast that South Africa repeated in exaggerated form the biblical story of the Tower of Babel whose builders, though united in purpose, were divided by language difficulties --to which South Africa (never exactly united in purpose) added the further complications of race, colour and cultural diversity.

title: The periodicals: Ariel (1986-10-31)
Excerpt: Given that the dispersal of English across the planet was a by-product of imperialism, it is inevitable that its situation in post-colonial nations should be a political question. The October 1984 number of Ariel was devoted to "Issues of Language," and despite the editorial's menacing references to Derrida, Lacan, Irigaray and Cixous, the best pieces dealt with the lived experience of ex-colonial language in a frankly untheoretical way.

title: Ohio University Press (1995-12-22)
Excerpt: Jolly looks at three South African writers to consider violence in the context of apartheid and colonialism and their inherent patriarchies. She also discusses the violence attendant upon the act of narration in the broader critiques of Kafka, Freud, Hegel, the post-colonial critics Jan Mohammed and Bhabha, and feminists such as Susan Suleiman.
works: "[Colonization, Violence and Narration in White South African Writing (1996)](apdp.work.000873)"

James.

title: Are There Underdeveloped Writers? (1965-05-27)
Excerpt: What are the prospects for publication for a writer in a new and developing country? These might at first sight appear gloomy indeed, if his country has no indigenous publishing industry. title: Thousands in riot after Pretoria poet is executed (1985-10-19)
Article title: Thousands in riot after Pretoria poet is executed
Excerpt: This article published in The Times, London, on Saturday 19th October 1985 centers on the state execution of a 30 year-old South African poet, Benjamin Moloise, convicted of killing a security policeman. According to Ray Kennedy, the author of the article, the poet was executed in Pretoria despite appeals against it from EEC countries, the Nordic government, and the Secretary General of the United Nations. The article reported that this killing was responsible for the eruption of riots in several South African cities where black South Africans demonstrated against whites and symbols of state authority deemed oppressive to the black person.

Lewis describes Ross as a literary midwife to young writers such the ones mentioned.
Notes: Yet it is to the London magazine that young writer still turn when thet are starting out on the literary life."

Master Smiles'

title: #NAME? (1965-04-01)
Excerpt: [Excerpt]: "There is one story in Mr. Richard Rive's selection which stings the tongue with the real taste of experience. Ironically enough, in this selection of modern English prose from Africa, it is a story translated from the Portuguese. We are not told by whom... What differences can be discerned between teh handling of the language by native English speakers like Jack Cope and by writers approaching it from another culture, with another music in their ears, like Achebe and Kariara? What popular idoms or dialects of English exist in Africa, and have any of these writers been able to come to terms with them? ... Again, there is none of the experimental prose now appearing in west Africa in the work of writers like Ibrahim Tahir, Gabriel Okara, and Babatunde Jones. All these are incomparably more interesting and liberating than most of what is offered here, with its conventional plots and undistinguished writing..."

title: 18-Month Sentence On Brutus (1964-01-10)
Excerpt: [Full Text]: "Denis Vincent Brutus, president of the South African Non-Racial Olympic Committee, was sentenced to 18 months imprisonment today by a Johannesburg magistrate on four charges of contravening a banning order and one of escaping from custody. Brutus was the centre of a diplomatic incident last September after he was shot down in a busy Johannesburg street by a police warrant officer as he made a dash for freedom. Brutus was banned and confined to the magisterial area of Johannesburg last year after his return from Europe where he had made representations about discrimination in Olympic teams. He broke his ban and went to Swaziland from where he intended to return to Europe to approach Olympic headquarters in Switzerland, but after crossing the border into Mozambique he was arrested by Portuguese secret police and returned to South Africa. Brutus said at the time and repeated in court today, while pleading in mitigation of sentence, that he had had a valid Rhodesian Federation passport. During the diplomatic row at that time Pretoria submitted that Brutus was a South African citizen. The magistrate ruled that Brutus's contention that his escape bid was made to draw attention to his situation was not altogether valid, but the court would take into account that he had been wounded, which was a partial penalty for his offence.
contributor.name: ["Brutus, Dennis Vincent"]

title: 19 nations join in Olympics protest (1976-07-20)
Excerpt: [Full Text]: "The number of countries which have withdrawn from the Olympic Games in protest at the New Zealand rugby tour of South Africa increased to 19 yesterday with the news that the team of Mali has been instructed to return home by their Minister of Sport. Thirteen countries have formally notified the International Committee of their withdrawal. They are Congo, Chad, Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, Zambia, Cameroon, Guyana, Niger, Togo, Uganda and Swaziland. Algeria, Iraq, Libya, and Upper Volta have verbally informed the IOC that they will not be taking part, and news was received yesterday from Cairo that Egypt is also pulling out. Before the news was received of Mali's marching orders, 303 competitors and 60 officials were listed as leaving the Olympics. This still left 6,934 competitors and 2,825 officials from 100 countries taking part with, in most cases, undiminished enthusiasm. Two of the chief boycott organizers have already left the battlefield. Abraham Ordia, of the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa, has flown home to Nigeria, and Denis Brutus, president of the South African Non-racial Olympic Committee, has left the Queen Elizabeth hotel, where his bemused elderly victims in the IOC are also housed, to return to his university in Chicago. Both men have obviously decided to leave the possibility of further withdrawals in the hands of the remaining uncommitted Caribbean, French-speaking African and Arab governments."
contributor.name: ["Brutus, Dennis Vincent"]

title: A change of address (2002-01-25)
Excerpt: [Excerpt]: Robert Potts reviews Geoffrey Hill's Speech! Speech! ... "One of the students whom Geoffrey Hill taught at Cambridge (1981-8) used to quote his tutor in letters to friends... Reading Geoffrey Hill can itself feel like receiving a reading list--one is frequently referred to texts and events with which one is unhappily unfamiliar--but the matter of Hill's 'difficulty' (his pun in The Triumph of Love, that he is 'charged with erudition', did little to allay criticism of his range of references) has surely been adequately dealt with, not least by the poet himself... The writers Chinua Achebe and Christopher Okigbo, variously alluded to, both worked for Nigerian radio before the Befran conflict, sinister and exemplary details of which are found throughout Speech! Speech! ..."

title: A garbled message (1990-05-18)
Excerpt: Watson compares the two anthologies of African poetry, one compiled by Stephen Gray and the other Jane Watts. Of Penguin's anthology, he writes, "No work to date so completely misrepresents the full spectrum of poetry from this part of the world, and seems so perversely designed to mislead readers who do not already have extensive independent knowledge of local political and cultural history... Gray claims that all nations of southern African belong to a single 'literary system' whose importance overrides any division of the area into separate nation-states." Of Watts, Watson has a more positive opinion, in that Watts instead makes the "essential point" that the work of black writers in South Africa is "very different from that of African writers elsewhere." He then writes that, "having presented these differences, [Jane Watts] is able to explain with admirable lucidity why black writing in this country has progressively assumed an identity all its own, and most particularly why it no longer conforms to Western aesthetic standards."
works: "[The Penguin Book of Southern African Verse (1989)](apdp.work.000230)"

title: A is for Art (1972-03-24)
Excerpt: [From the book reviewer, unnamed]: "Among the enemies of promise now confronting African literature it is possible to include the American university. Kofi Awoonor is a learned Ghanaian poet with an evident gift for narrative (when he chooses to exercise it) and he ought to be a good novelist...All this is fascinating: and the sketches add up to a mysterious but not wholly opaque portrait of Amamu and an account of his disintegration. There is no doubt that Kofi Awoonor could write a very good novel."

title: A Literature in the Making (1935-05-31)
Excerpt: Professor J. P. R. Wallis writes of the development of poetry and literature in South Africa. He suggests that "the insurmountable obstacle in the way of those who would discourse of South African literature is that as yet it does not exist," in that the Union of the nation has "not unity in any intimate spiritual sense of the word." Wallis continues in exploring the different authors that are working in South Africa, such as poets F. Carey Slater, Roy Campbell, and Charles Murray, among other prose writers.

title: A New Look in Writing (1960-05-31)
Excerpt: "History has brought together in South Africa two languages so closley related that if one were to try to express their relationship in familiar terms, one could possibly say they are first cousins. Although this relationship right through the nineteenth century and deep into the present was marred by keen and sometimes even bitter rivalry, conditions are now such that in the literary field at least Afrikaans and English not only are a source of mutual inspiration, but to a large degree also complement each other... "
Notes: W. E. G. Louw writes on poets in South Africa from the early 1900s to the 1950s.

title: A Plea for Afrikaans (1936-11-21)
Excerpt: T. J. Harhoff's book recounts the origins and development of the Afrikaans language in South Africa. Of African poetry, critic du Plessis writes, "Afrikaans has still a long way to go before it realizes all the hopes of its ardent supporters: but it has some poets and one or two prose-writers whose measure would not be diminished by European standards. The language is bold, simple, humorous, vital and vigorous, and is sufficiently flexible for any venturesome and inventive writer who wishes to express many shades of thought." du Plessis then quotes from Harhoff's book, in which Harhoff discusses Roy Campbell.

title: A poet in arms (guns, sub-machine 9mm, 1007) (1966-10-30)
Excerpt: [Full Text]: "The 20th century has been sadly short of poets doubling as men of action; the passion of W. B. Yeats and Ezra Pound was confined to the literary fringe of revoution, and only the poets of the Irish and Spanish Republics, Patrick Pearse, and Garcia Lorca, seem fit to be considered in the same breath as Goethe and Byron. Last week's Insight story on running illicit arms to Nigeria ("Gun-running via Birminham") has, however, produced a contemporary contender for the role, a distinguished Nigerian poet, Christopher Okigbo. Okigbo, a member of the beleagured Ibo tribe from Eastern Nigeria, planned the deal with a French ex-policeman, Paul Favier to transport 1,007 sub-machine guns to defend the Ibo against the ravages of the Hausa tribesmen from Northern Nigeria. After a short stay in Geneva, where the negotiations with Favier took place, Okigbo flew to Rotterdam shortly before an ancient DC 4 took off on its ill-fated flight. Indeed, he was due to travel with the aircraft, but fortuitously changed his mind at the last moment. When the aircraft crashed in Cameroun just north of the Nigerian border two days later, a suitcase and some books belonging to Okigbo were found among the wreckage. CLASSICAL SCHOLAR. Born in 1932, Okigbo was educated at the Ibadan University where he was a classical scholar. After graduation, he became private secretary to the Nigerian Minister of Research and Information, but two years later he left to teach, and eventually represented the Cambridge University Press in West Africa. His poetry, as yet, shows no signs of political commitment. Although in one of his T. S. Eliot-inspired works the refrain reads: "& the mortor is not yet dry..."; it refers, prosaically, to construction material not weapons of war. But Okigbo has during the last month gathered the raw material for what could, if he writes it, be the first epic poem about an illicit arms deal."

title: A Poet of South Africa (1947-05-31)
Excerpt: The critic writes, of F. C. Slater's poetry collection, "The selection contains only a few pieces on topics of an abstract kind, aesthetic or philosophical; one of hte few is a generous and curious fancy concerning all the activities and the mutations of the poetic spirit. But the scarcity of such detached reflections is not to be misunderstood; for the whole book is founded in reflective habit and maturity through which the national theme so prominent in it is measured and given its setting in the landscape of all human affairs. The secret of his whole structure is his comprehension of life, thought and art beyond geographical boundaries."

title: A South African Poet (2002-06-20)
Excerpt: "South Africa, where a new era is now beginning, has not produced much poetry, and its chief poet has been forgotten. This little volume should save Thomas Pringle, if only for a little while longer, from the oblivion which has been fast closing over him. For he was a genuine poet in his way... South Africa, it seemed, was a to have a University before she had a literature; but somehow the muse always gets ahead of learning and pegs out the first claim; and the patrons of literature arrive to find her seated, patient, and smiling in her poverty. This little book, which can be slipped into the waistcoat pocket, contains (we daresay) the beginnings of South African poetry, and professors in Cape Town will some day start their lectures with Thomas Pringle."

title: A World of Riches (1975-04-13)
Excerpt: Putting novels, plays, verse, essays and so on into literary categories is an important but not very impressive exercise. It matters because the written word is so huge, various, and surprising that some sort of mark is needed for tourists--and we are all tourists. But one category that does not work is that of "black African literature." Africa is too rich and too varous for that box to hold very much...

title: Africa on Record (1964-06-11)
Excerpt: This article was written in The Times Literary Supplement of Thursday, June 11, 1964 by Maurice Bowra and M. Bowra. The article, "Africa on Record", focused on the importance of oral literature in societies where there are no means of recording, in writing, the compositions that constitute such people's literature. It lamented the scant attention paid to oral literature in Africa at that period and mentioned that what was available was gathered by missionaries, officials, and travelers, and that even those materials were left in the hands of private enterprise. The authors maintained that the best way to understand Africa properly was to do so from the inside, through the oral productions of its people. In the necessary urgency to do that, the authors traced such efforts that had made useful contribution in this direction. Such efforts included the Oxford University Press that published the first four volumes of "The Oxford Library of African Literature". This according to the authors had helped preserve habits and memories derived from much earlier times. The authors also mentioned other works of value such as "The Heroic Recitations of the Bahima of Ankole" written by Henry F. Morris and "Somali Poetry: An Introduction" by W.H. Whiteley. They also mentioned how literary production continued in different forms with people like J.E. Caseley Hayford, T. Mofolo. B. Diop, until it got to others such as the Nigerian poet, Gabriel Okara.
works: "[Somali Poetry: An Introduction (1964)](apdp.work.000212);;;[A Selection of African Prose (1964)](apdp.work.000211)"
Notes: Maurice Bowra presents multiple collections of African poetry and discusses their value.

title: Africa speaks (1972-04-09)
Excerpt: [Excerpt]: "In the tourist bazaars of Dar es Salaam the most common form of 'native art' is carved wooden animals--elephants, giraffes, crocodiles in smooth black wood which turns out not to be ebony.... Many of their authors will not have faced the question which their unique position asks them; of those that have, a surprising number will turn out to belong to that amazing generation of Nigerians--it includes Chinua Achebe, Wole Soyinka, J. P. Clark, Christopher Okigbo--who made their debuts in the late Fifties and early Sixties. For these writers, examined in detail in Bruce King's Introduction to Nigerian Literature, a consciousness of their own cultural dilemma proved not an inhibition but a spur. Unlike Tutuola, whose imaginatively translated Yoruba foklore owes its richness as much to mistranslation of Yoruba as to a feeling for the adopted language itself, they are constantly aware of their responsibilites... Those who have picked the clearest path are without doubt the Ibo novelist Chinua Achebe and the Yoruba playwright Wole Soyinka. Soyinka is a poet, in love with words, images and myths, whose plays blend in a unique mixture all the rich formal elements of European drama with the haunting complexities of African ritual. The accomodation here between teh two cultures is complete. Gerald Moore's Wole Soyinka is a useful introduction for the student, but of course there is no substitute for reading or, if possible, seeing Soyinka's marvellous plays..."

title: African Adventurer: The life of a Nigerian maverick makes for a challenging read (2006-05-06)
Article title: African Adventurer: The life of a Nigerian maverick makes for a challenging read
Excerpt: Politically engage young writers are supposed to mellow when they grow old. With experience and recognition, you somehow expect them to become more settled in their chosen craft, less fired-up, more removed from the fray. But not Wole Soyinka. Twenty years after winning the Nobel Prize for literature, the first African to do so, he has pitched himself back into the seething politics of Nigeria, "the place I never should have left". [David White reviews Wole Soyinka's autobiographical work.]
works: "[You Must Set Forth at Dawn: A Memoir (2007)](apdp.work.000210)"

title: African Culture Asserted After Struggle (1976-07-22)
Excerpt: "The pre-colonial artistic heritage of Nigeria suffered decay while the country was under British rule. Both Christianity, the religion of the colonial masters, and Islam, which made impressive gains under Pax Britannica, were opposed to manifestations of their converts' ancestral religions, although the latter was more tolerant of them... But the most exciting developments have been in literature, where the late Christopher Okigbo, the poet, Chinua Achebe, a novelist and poet, and Wole Soyinka, poet, playwright, novelist, have proved themselves superb craftsmen who leave the reader in no doubt of their identity, yet handle the English language with the same confidence as the best of their native English-speaking contemporaries."

title: African dramatist's new play (1966-09-30)
Excerpt: The English Stage Company has now completed its plans for the 1966-67 season at the Royal Court Theatre. After Three Men for Colverton, which has just opened, and Macbeth, with Sir Alec Guinness and Simone Signoret, on October 20, will come the first performance of Wole Soyinka's The Lion and the Jewel. This is to be the first of two productions of plays by Wole Soyinka to be presented by the English Stage Company in conjunction with the Ijinle players, the group of African actors living in London who recently produced The Trials of Brother Jero at the Hampstead Theatre Club. The Lion and the Jewel opens on November 30 and will be directed by Desmond O'Donovan...

title: African Exports (1973-07-27)
Excerpt: [Excerpt]: "Today the African novelist is established, not only in profusion among O and A level syllabuses within Africa but also in numerous English literature courses in the Western world... Complementing today's easy availability of the work of African authors (Heinemann's excellent 'African Writers Series' has nearly 150 titles to its credit), Evans Brothers have begun publishing a 'Modern African Writers' series... Each volume adopts a similar pattern, with a brief biographical introduction followed by a critical analysis resting on an exploration of the writer's major works. Thus the aim is fulfiled of telling us something about the present state of criticism in African literature as well as about the work of its principal exponents. 'Schools' are rigorously excluded. Short but useful bibliographies (including lists of critical works as well) and indexes (that for the Okigbo volume, compiled by Valerie Chandler, is a model of its kind) compete the books..."

title: African fiction: a sense of urgency (1976-12-12)
Article title: African fiction: a sense of urgency
Excerpt: [Excerpt]: "One of NIgeria's most distinguished poets, Christopher Okigbo (sadly killed in action during the Biafran war) declared firmly: 'There is no African literature. There is good writing and bad writing--that's all.' It's an admirable statement, but not the whole story. His friend and fellow Ibo, the novelist Chinua Achebe, leaned perhaps too far the other way: 'It is clear to me that an Africna creative writer who tries to avoid the big social and political issues of contemporary Africa will end up being completely irrelevant.' ..."

title: African Honeymoon (1972-03-26)
Excerpt:
Frank Norman writes an article regarding his trip to South Africa and how his preconceived notions of the country line up with the actuality. He discusses he and his wife's flight in, how he has been warned by friends to "trust no-one," and South African apartheid. At a cocktail party with friends, he meets Oswald Joseph Mtshali, the poet, of whom he says: "His poems are lyrical and powerfully composed. They are a cry of anguish for the plight of the black man in South Africa and are often devastatingly critical of the Vorstere regime. But it cannot be said that they are a call to arms, which is doubtless why publication has been permitted -- in order that the world can see how liberal the South African Government really is."

"In the evening Nadine gave a cocktail party for us, so that we could meet some of the local literati, journalists and the like. Notable among the guests was Oswald Joseph Mtshali, a black African poet whose book, Sounds of a Cowhide, is a run away bestseller among both black and white readers."
contributor.name: ["Mtshali, Oswald Mbuyiseni"]
commentaries_relation: "[Oswald Joseph Mbuyiseni Mtshali: A South African Poet Whose Collection’s Sales Shocked Critics](apdp.commentary.000014)"

title: African Playwright and Poet (1959-11-02)
Excerpt: We must hope that the reception given at the Royal Court last night to verses and songs by Mr. Wole Soyinka and to his one act play The Invention will make this Nigerian writer less suspicious of the London theatre than he gives the impression of being. Whenever he allowed a reader or a character to speak directly to the audience, the audience responded. It went more than half way towrads doing so even when Mr. Soyinka plainly was not addressing it. If he thinks this was prompted by the thing he hates most, a patronizing attitude on the part of a white audience, it will be a pity. It was prompted by respect for his gift for words. When his words were clear, clarity was their most striking quality. At those times he had written briefly, without repeating himself, and then suddenly the wish to do just that, to say it all over again, became too strong for him. What his last comment was on the relationship between the races most of us will never know. For instead of making it at the end of The Invention he made a joke, or else, figuratively speaking, he mumbled. So the comment was lost. For us, a pity.
contributor.name: ["Soyinka , Wole 'Akinwande Oluwole Babatunde'"]
commentaries_relation: "[Wole Soyinka in The Times Advertisements and Announcements between 1965 and 1983](apdp.commentary.000003)"

title: African Poems of Thomas Pringle (1991-02-22)
Excerpt: Stephen Watson reviews the poetry collection of Thomas Pringle, who is a Scottish poet considered to be the "father of South African poetry": "On the face of it, the title might seem well-deserved. He was undoubtedly the first of the nineteenth-century colonial poets to take on the general conditions of life in the Colony as his subject matter. Moreover, his poetry's early, often outraged protests against white tyranny, as well as its championing of the dispossessed and maligned black peoples, have made him the obvious founding father of that tradition of protest poetry which has been more or less dominant in South Africa in the past few decades." Watson writes of Roy Campbell that Pringle fathered few successors of his kind of poetry, and the only "significant child" was Campbell, who appears a century later.
contributor.name: ["Campbell, Roy", "Pringle, Thomas"]
creator.name: ["Watson, Stephen"]

title: African Writers Series reaches 100 (1972-02-25)
Excerpt: Advertisement for the African Wrtiers Series; list of the first 100 publications. "The 100th title in this world-famous paperback series, Girls at War, short stories by Chinua Achebe is published on 28th February at 30p. Achebe has been Editorial Adviser to the series since it began in 1962 with his Things Fall Apart. The ten years between has seen the flowering of African writing, and the best of this--fiction, poetry, and drama--is in this series."

title: Afrikaans poet released (1982-12-06)
Excerpt:
Mr Breyten Breytenbach, South Africa's most famous living Afrikaans poet, has been released from prison after serving seven of the nine years to which he was sentenced in 1975 for promoting the aims of the banned African National Congress (ANC).
By far the best known white political prisoner in South Africa, Mr Breytenbach is also the first prisoner of note to be freed under a new policy announced earlier this year by Mr Kobie Coetsee, the Minister of Justice, which makes it possible for those convicted of "offenses against the security of the state" to qualify for remission of sentence.
[Article continues to describe how political prisoners are chosen for release.]
contributor.name: ["Breytenbach, Breyten"]

title: Agisymbolic (1966-09-08)
Excerpt: The review entitled Agisymbolic is critical of Janheinz Jahn collection of works; the "heterogenous material" included in his book varies from "Juan Latino, who wrote bad poems in Latin in praise of Spanish noblemen; Langston Hughes pleading for sympathy; Somali poets imitating Arabic ideas of chivalry," and so on. The critic is skeptical of Jahn's suggestion that all of "the black African cultures south of the Sahara form a cultural unit" and that they can be collectively called Agisymbia. Jahn defines neo-African literature all writing that contains Agisymbian-style elements, but never truly explains what an "Agisymbian" element includes.

title: Ain't I a woman (1992-12-11)
Excerpt: "Ain't I a Woman" by critic Maya Jaggi reviews "Daughters of Africa," an anthology edited by Margaret Busby. Excerpt: "Daughters of Africa draws together samples of work by more than 200 women of African descent, from the continent itself to the diaspora... Toni Morrison uses the narrator's voice as chorus, with echoes of black church music and jazz, as does Ghanaian, Ama Ata Aidoo, in her mischievous satires on urban materialism and sexual relations."

title: Akamba, Yoruba, Swahili (1967-03-23)
Excerpt: [Ulli Beier reviews two books, Thet Content and Form of Yoruba Ijala by S. A. Babalola and Poems from Kenya by Ahmad Nassir bin Juma Bhalo.] "The editors of the Oxford Library of African Literature hope that 'compositions in local languages will make their impact on world literature as those of India and China have done for many years.' It is not likely that this series--nine volumes have so far appeared--will make much impact ont he literary world.... To make African literature come alive in English is a formidable task. But it can be done, as was proved by Ugandan poet Okot p'Bitek, whose brilliant translation of his own original Acholi poem Song of Lawino was reviewed in the TLS of February 16."

title: All the Trouble in the World- Dr. Mairi J Blackings comments a bold exploration of the turmoil in Africa (1996-11-02)
Article title: All the Trouble in the World- Dr. Mairi J Blackings comments a bold exploration of the turmoil in Africa
Excerpt: This is a piece written by Dr Mairi J. Blackings. Published in Financial Times of Saturday, November 2, 1996, this piece focuses on a book "The Open Sore of a Continent" by Wole Soyinka, a Nigerian poet and Africa's first Nobel Laureate. Dr Blackings entitled his article "All the Trouble in the World" and it reviews and extols Soyinka's achievement in the work. He describes Soyinka as a "skilled observer" owing to his depiction of the political incidents in Nigeria under military dictatorship and how that was undermining the true promise of development held by the country and also how such situation was the problem of other African countries.
works: "[The Open Sore of a Continent: A Personal Narrative of the Nigerian Crisis (1997)](apdp.work.000199)"

title: Anowa (1991-04-09)
Excerpt: Malcolm Rutherford reviews Ama Ata Aidoo's play "Anowa." Excerpt: "Some of the touches, like the introductory and closing music, are distinctly West African. But do not go to see Anowa looking for something exotic. What will strike you is not how different it is from developed western culture, but how similar. It is a very well-constructed, thoughtful piece. Anowa is played with superb self-control by Joy Elias-Rilwan, as is Kofi by David Harewood. The play is directed by Dele Charley and was written by Ama Ata Aidoo as long ago as 1970."

title: Apartheid and Sport: The Logic of Denis Howell's Approach (1969-10-21)
Article title: Apartheid and Sport: The Logic of Denis Howell's Approach
Excerpt: "If the Minister for Sport, Mr. Denis Howell, has his way we will be deprived next year of the opportunity of seeing the South African cricket team in action. Choosing his words with care, Mr. Howell said in a television interview at the week-end: 'I personally don't think the South African team should come. I Have no time for sport based on racial considerations. Their sport certainly is, and the selection of their team certainly is." ...By this I mean far more than the cancellation of the New Zealand rugby tour in 1964, or the fiasco over the MCC tour last year. I could take the story back as far as 1956, when the International Table Tennis Federation excluded from membership the all-white official South African Table-Tennis Association in favour of an unofficial group whose rules allowed ping-pong across the colour line. But it is best to begin with 1962, when the "South African non-racial Open Committee for Olympic Sports"--Sanroc--was formed. This group worked originally inside the Republic but it has since exiled itself to London since its president, Denis Brutus, left his home country in 1966 after a 22-month term served mostly on Robben Island..."

title: Apartheid's arch-enemy wins right of asylum (1983-09-08)
Article title: Apartheid's arch-enemy wins right of asylum
Excerpt: New York writer Trevor Fishlock reports: "Dennis Brutus, a leading opponent of apartheid who headed the campaign to have South Africa expelled from the Olympic Games, has won his fight against deportation from the United States. A judge in Chicago granted him political asylum..."

title: Arts Council Awards for Two Playwrights (1967-06-30)
Article title: Arts Council Awards for Two Playwrights
Excerpt: Lord Goodman, chairman of the Arts Council, is to present awards of 500 each to two playwrights to-day. Wole Soyinka and Tom Stoppard are the first writers to receive the John Whiting Award, which is given to British or Commonwealth playwrights for a play or plays, either read in script form or seen in production during the year, which show a new and distinctive development in dramatic writing... The 1966-67 award will be made jointly to: Wole Soyinka, for plays published in a volume of "Five Plays" including the following produced in this country for the first time during the year. The lion and the jewel (Royal Court Theatre), and Trials of brother Jero (Hamstead Theatre Club); and Tom Stoppard, for his play Rosencrantz and Guildenstein are dead (National Theatre).

title: At the crossroads of cultures (1975-10-17)
Excerpt: [Excerpt]: Nadine Gorimer reviews Chinua Achebe's collection of essays Morning Yet on Creation Day. "Named by Christianized parents after Queen Victoria's beloved; master of the colonial master's tongue, splendidly appropriating it to interpret his country's and people's past; bold user of freedom won by Africa against white domination; Albert Chinualumogu became Chinua Achebe is himself the definitive African experience... Alternatively, there are writers who regard the category "African writer" (with its concomitant, African critic?) as a patronizing relegation to literary provincialism. Achebe quotes Nigeria's finest poet, Christopher Okigbo: "There is no African literature. There is good writing and bad writing--that's all." ..."

title: Attempting the pen (1989-09-22)
Excerpt: Angela Leighton reviews three anthologies: "Anthology of British Women Writers," "Longman Anthology of World Literature by Women," and "Dictionary of British Women Writers." Excerpt: "Anthologies serve many purposes. They may blaze a trail of new writing, or simply confirm popular tastes of the day. They may change the literary consciousness of an age, or merely look good on the coffee table... A short story by the Ghanaian Ama Ata Aidoo is followed by two poems by the Cuban Cuza Male, and three very funny poems on women and colonialism by the Jamaican Louise Bennett are followed by Doris Lessing's sophisticated satire of male sexism in a short story called 'A Woman on a Roof.' ..."

title: Avant ou a Rebours?  (1964-09-03)
Excerpt: [Excerpt]: "Is the avant-garde a subject of indifference to artists outside the western world? Is it generally regarded elsewhere as a curious manifestation of western neuroticism or subjectivisim or decadence? The first special number of The Times Literary Supplement on this theme clearly anticipated some such answer and there are many reasons why one might be tempted to give it... There are two spurs which are likely to gaod the non-European writer more and more in the direction of experiment in the coming years. First, the sense of alienation which is apt to pursue him everywhere once he becomes fully aware, in the search for an identity, of what he is not... Secondly, those who are attempting to record in English or in French the lives of people who do not spak them are immediately confronted with the absolute necessity to experiment with langauge. They may attempt to transfer the imagery, the speech-rhythms, or even, as Gabriel Okara of Nigeria has done in one interesting chapter, the actual syntax of vernacular speech. Whatever they do, they cannot evade the problem, for language taken straight from the European novel or stage will ring falser than any experiment..."

title: Behind the lines (1987-05-15)
Excerpt: This article covers the two-day "crammed and curious" conference called The Politics of Exile, organized by the Third World Foundation and South magazine at the Institute for Contemporary Arts. "The real politicians had stayed away, offering a wide variety of excuses: they didn't feel like entering this kind of forum, it was too potentially compromising, they'd have to have the authority of a central committee... Instead, it was the writers and intellectuals who jostled for space in the programme to talk about the Latin American, African, Middle-Eastern, and South Asian experiences. So the politics were filtered through very self-conscious lenses." Of African poets, Sage writes, "As someone else pointed out, exiles must always be distiguished from refugees, they don't have the collective innocence of victims... Educated and articulate exiles, said the banished South African poet Dennis Brutus (famed as the inspirer of the sporting boycott), form a new wandering tribe -- the Bintu. They've been to conferences on the nature of exile just about everywhere, even Oklahoma."

title: Black man's burden (1981-11-06)
Excerpt: [Niven reviews Towards the Decolonization of African Literature] "Toward the Decolonization of African Literature is dedicated to thirty-three Third World intellectuals, "expemplary inciters against toleration of our oppressed condition... The main accusation levelled here is that European critics have attempted to annex African literature for themselves. If a book is written in English or French then it is seen as a by-product or subdivision of the Great Tradition, of Modernism, or of some other beautified cultural monolith... They defend African orature against its alleged deficiencies in characterization and range of expression, and witheringly expose the pretensions of European critics who half get the point and so miss it by miles--in, for example, comparing the brevity of many African novels with oral tales... Toward the Decolonization of African Literature is not a pioneer study but it articulates a point of view which is increasingly heard among African critics and which has not previously been marshalled with so much damning quotation. It restores to literary criticism a brio, verging at times on insult, which is rare in Western criticism, where so often genteel irony or theoretical contortions are substituted for plain-spoken assertion of a fully held point of view. Also, the book is fundamentally right..."

title: Black Orpheus (1966-07-28)
Excerpt: Thorpe reviews Ulli Beier's anthology of African Poetry, which includes fifty-four poems translated from twenty-six languages. The collection purports to be for students in Africa to study English poetry, but Thorpe is critical of the anthology's lack of inclusion of poems in the African version, as well. He writes, "Offering them only an English text half concedes - with unintentional irony - the defeat of the languages many are being educated away from."

title: Black poet defiant in face of death (1985-10-18)
Article title: Black poet defiant in face of death
Excerpt:
The mother of Benjamin Moloise, the poet convicted of killing a black security policeman, yesterday sang the song he intends to chant as he is led to the gallows in Pretoria Central prison today...
Mrs. Moloise said her son gave a clenched fist black nationalist salute as he was led from the interview room back to his cell...
The ANC said that if Moloise goes to the gallows his death would be avenged "in every corner of our land."
contributor.name: ["Moloise, Benjamin"]

title: Black poet reprieved (1985-08-21)
Excerpt: Lawyers won a 21-day stay of execution for black South African poet Benjamin Moloise who was due to have been hanged in Pretoria this morning for killing a policeman.
Permissions: © The Financial Times Limited. All rights reserved.
